results.content: Generally, the course is just ok, very basic intro, so yes it has given me a high level overview of Thymeleaf, but like many other comments I read, I found myself consistently playing the video on quick speeds or skipping through the much of the video because there was way too much talking, especially the introductions, the overviews and the conclusions (For example, one of the 2m3sec videos John only teaches for 40 secs, the other time is intro and ending summary).  I think this course could have been completed in about half the time (if not quicker) if you were to remove the verbosity.  All in all, I got the basics of Thymeleaf. We just don't need to hear or see that you are John the Spring Framework Guru on every video introduction. In addition, there is just no need to show your mini Spring Framework Guru logo and sound at the beginning and end of every video, it can quickly get annoying.

I think this course could have been completed in about half the time (if not quicker) if you were to remove the verbosity. All in all, I got the basics of Thymeleaf. We just don't need to hear or see that you are John the Spring Framework Guru on every video introduction. results.content:
This is a pretty good course that got me on my feet and running in no time. Thymeleaf documentation has a section on Spring, but not Spring Boot, and it's not super easy to quickly set everything up and get started, figure out where all the templates go and what the stucture of 'resources' should look like. This course helped me set everything up, let me start playing with it and showcased the main Thymeleaf features and how it integrates with Spring Boot. From that point, further study is necessary to master the topic, which is fair, but the course itself covers quite a lot. Additional debugging and updating to the latest Thymeleaf and Spring Boot versions is necessary in places, but I did not find it annoying or hard to do. 
I found myself wishing for the coding assignments to be in a printed form; instead the instructor just says what needs to be done while we're looking at him speaking, without making it possible to also read the instructions. I felt that just including those instructions in the corresponding sections together with links to the code would go a long way. I found it repetitive and unnecessary that the instructor reiterated what they just did in front of you after coding something new, since I just saw what was done and remember it quite well, I felt it took a long time and was unnecessarily detailed, and I was anxious to just skip it in case something else important was added. 
I also found myself wishing for the music intro at the start and end of each video to go away, as it took a considerable part of videos that are a few minutes long. Thankfully the instructor removed the majority of the intro at the start in later videos, and although he left the end section, it made it a considerably better experience for me overall.
All in all, it's a pretty good course that delivers on what it promises, I'd recommend it to anyone who needs to get their feet wet quickly with Spring Boot and Thymeleaf.
results.content_html:

Thymeleaf documentation has a section on Spring, but not Spring Boot, and it's not super easy to quickly set everything up and get started, figure out where all the templates go and what the stucture of 'resources' should look like. This course helped me set everything up, let me start playing with it and showcased the main Thymeleaf features and how it integrates with Spring Boot. From that point, further study is necessary to master the topic, which is fair, but the course itself covers quite a lot. Additional debugging and updating to the latest Thymeleaf and Spring Boot versions is necessary in places, but I did not find it annoying or hard to do.
I found myself wishing for the coding assignments to be in a printed form; instead the instructor just says what needs to be done while we're looking at him speaking, without making it possible to also read the instructions. I felt that just including those instructions in the corresponding sections together with links to the code would go a long way. I found it repetitive and unnecessary that the instructor reiterated what they just did in front of you after coding something new, since I just saw what was done and remember it quite well, I felt it took a long time and was unnecessarily detailed, and I was anxious to just skip it in case something else important was added.
I also found myself wishing for the music intro at the start and end of each video to go away, as it took a considerable part of videos that are a few minutes long. Thankfully the instructor removed the majority of the intro at the start in later videos, and although he left the end section, it made it a considerably better experience for me overall.
All in all, it's a pretty good course that delivers on what it promises, I'd recommend it to anyone who needs to get their feet wet quickly with Spring Boot and Thymeleaf.

results.content:
I think the HTML for this type of course was too complex. Yes, it's nice to seen refined looking web pages, but as the instructor himself said, this is a course on Thymeleaf integration with Spring. Complex web pages tend to obstruct this goal. Simpler web pages with far less html would have been a better choice. 

This class is about 3 years old, as a result, you can't get answers to any posted questions. I don't know if Udemy has a standard for how long the author of a course must monitor and answer questions.

Many aspects of Thymeleaf you would want in a true application, were not covered. For example, extending the UserDetails interface to include more customized data. 

The instructor did not delve into the differences for Thymeleaf tags, such as 

th:href="@{...}" 
th:text="#{.....}" 
th:text="${....}"

What do the @, #, $ mean, when to use one over another? The only way you learn which to use and when, is by copying from the lectured, which may not include all use cases.

There is a lot of assumed knowledge for this course, like working with Git, or setting up a Resource Bundle in IntelliJ. I realize this is not a course on those subjects, but in other Udemy courses I've taken, the authors will still walk you through tasks like these, to make sure you are set up correctly. For example, in another course I took, the instructor walked you through setting up Tomcat, getting Eclipse to work with that version of Tomcat, setting up databases... This saves the students a lot of frustration in making sure our development environments are set up properly.

This class is about 3 years old, as a result, you can't get answers to any posted questions. I don't know if Udemy has a standard for how long the author of a course must monitor and answer questions.

Many aspects of Thymeleaf you would want in a true application, were not covered. For example, extending the UserDetails interface to include more customized data.

The instructor did not delve into the differences for Thymeleaf tags, such as

What do the @, #, $ mean, when to use one over another? The only way you learn which to use and when, is by copying from the lectured, which may not include all use cases.

There is a lot of assumed knowledge for this course, like working with Git, or setting up a Resource Bundle in IntelliJ. I realize this is not a course on those subjects, but in other Udemy courses I've taken, the authors will still walk you through tasks like these, to make sure you are set up correctly. For example, in another course I took, the instructor walked you through setting up Tomcat, getting Eclipse to work with that version of Tomcat, setting up databases... This saves the students a lot of frustration in making sure our development environments are set up properly.

results.content:
The videos for this course were originally shot in 2016 and haven't been updated. I purchased this course in part because it said "Last updated 11/2019" in the synopsis. That appears to be false.

If you want to follow along with the instructor's code samples from Git, you'll be stuck on Spring Boot 1.x and Bootstrap 3.x. The Git repo that is referenced in the lectures for obtaining the source code to start each section has not been updated since 2016 either. Some URLs to images in the 'starting point' code examples are no longer valid. For example, the course images on 'index.html' have invalid 'src' links in the img tags and will display nothing. It would help a lot if the instructor or his teaching assistant were to do a code update in the repo branches to fix things that no longer work correctly in 2020. I'm not talking about a rewrite of the course. I would just like to see obviously broken code/pages fixed so students can still follow along with the videos in 2020.

The course gets much better around Section 5. The stale content is less of an issue because the course starts to focus on specific features of Spring Boot and Thymeleaf, and one can search for the most up-to-date documentation for each feature if things have changed in 2020.

This would have been a 5-star course in 2016/2017. It just got stale and hasn't been maintained.

results.content:
I have some basic knowledge of Spring and front end web development, and want to learn fundamental of Thymeleaf and it's integration with Bootstrap and Spring Boot. This course just meets my needs. Thanks for John Thompson's excellent course!
Through this course I have learned how to convert an html page with Bootstrap into Thymeleaf template which can be used by Spring Boot to show dynamic contents. The Thymeleaf extension for Spring Security and Spring Boot DevTools are also very useful features. The concept explanation is concise and just easy to understand.
The only problem I encountered is the image url in index.html which seems to access Heroku resource, but that page says "There's nothing here, yet." And I don't know why the "src" attribute can be used like this without any protocol prefix:
//d6xfpzo6h49n1.cloudfront.net/BXwTFNXDD4SjVt6H78-It1YgNj8=/fit-in/705x0/https://d2vvqscadf4c1f.cloudfront.net/scgeIJ9wRGGNWvK0jAld_ThumbFREE_01.png
Anyway this is a great course for me! And I hope others who also want to learn Thymeleaf and Spring Boot will enroll this course and learn from it!
results.content_html:
I have some basic knowledge of Spring and front end web development, and want to learn fundamental of Thymeleaf and it's integration with Bootstrap and Spring Boot. This course just meets my needs. Thanks for John Thompson's excellent course!
Through this course I have learned how to convert an html page with Bootstrap into Thymeleaf template which can be used by Spring Boot to show dynamic contents. The Thymeleaf extension for Spring Security and Spring Boot DevTools are also very useful features. The concept explanation is concise and just easy to understand.
The only problem I encountered is the image url in index.html which seems to access Heroku resource, but that page says "There's nothing here, yet." And I don't know why the "src" attribute can be used like this without any protocol prefix:
//d6xfpzo6h49n1.cloudfront.net/BXwTFNXDD4SjVt6H78-It1YgNj8=/fit-in/705x0/https://d2vvqscadf4c1f.cloudfront.net/scgeIJ9wRGGNWvK0jAld_ThumbFREE_01.png
Anyway this is a great course for me! And I hope others who also want to learn Thymeleaf and Spring Boot will enroll this course and learn from it!

results.content: Course is good. The main benefit is that It helped me to give required information on Thymeleaf implementation using security in spring boot so that I complete my office assignment. Jhon Thompson gave me that quick information. I went through his course within week. Although course is good but he could have explain bit more on thymeleaf expression.
results.content_html: Course is good. The main benefit is that It helped me to give required information on Thymeleaf implementation using security in spring boot so that I complete my office assignment. Jhon Thompson gave me that quick information. I went through his course within week. Although course is good but he could have explain bit more on thymeleaf expression.

results.content:
This course is quite extensive and John does explain the thymeleaf templating engine integration with Spring framework really well. However, I find him a little too repetitive on what he will cover and what he covered during each class (it is a waste of time). Each recap takes around 90s in a almost any lecture which are usually 4-6 minutes long. Another time wasters are typos that could be easily avoided and would make this course shorter. Basically, great class that needs some editing to achieve refined, polished look. This gives me an impression that this course was rushed in. John is a really knowledgeable instructor but the course could be shorter (or more extensive in the same time). 
If you want to see what I mean please check courses offered by Anthony Alicea (no time waster there whatsoever). Should John add some sections to this course I will gladly take a look at them.

results.content: A very good course on Thymeleaf. A little updating needs to be done but using spring boot 2.x instead of one only required a few things to fix once I found the solution.
results.content_html: A very good course on Thymeleaf. A little updating needs to be done but using spring boot 2.x instead of one only required a few things to fix once I found the solution.

results.content: This course is very good if one is interested in learning about Thymeleaf and how well it integrates with Spring. John does provide brief information about the relevant spring sub-project before integrating it with thymeleaf and this is pretty informative for us to carry on.
results.content_html: This course is very good if one is interested in learning about Thymeleaf and how well it integrates with Spring. John does provide brief information about the relevant spring sub-project before integrating it with thymeleaf and this is pretty informative for us to carry on.

results.content:
It is a very complete course. John explains in a concise way enough points to use the Thymeleaf template engine, in addition to real use cases, which allows you to instantly apply the examples in your day to day and do not fall into oblivion.

It is true that some points require knowledge of other areas, such as Spring Security or Bootstrap, but this is explained explicitly by the instructor. It is an essential course
results.content_html:
It is a very complete course. John explains in a concise way enough points to use the Thymeleaf template engine, in addition to real use cases, which allows you to instantly apply the examples in your day to day and do not fall into oblivion.

It is true that some points require knowledge of other areas, such as Spring Security or Bootstrap, but this is explained explicitly by the instructor. It is an essential course

results.content:
This course did a great job on jumpstarting me on using Thymeleaf.  The material is presented well, isn't too longwinded, and puts the learner in a good position to use the templating engine.  I also appreciate that some non-focus areas were covered, inclusion of the bootstrap JS framework and Spring / Thymeleaf security integration are greatly appreciated.

I also appreciate that later in the course the intro is reduced to a quiet animated graphic vs. the full multi-media experience that the outro contains - when watching many videos in a row having the outro feed right into the intro of the next lesson with both having full fanfare is very distracting.  It would be good if this was likewise fixed in the earlier lessons as well.

Thank you for a great class!  I'll be looking into your other Spring classes!
results.content_html:
This course did a great job on jumpstarting me on using Thymeleaf. The material is presented well, isn't too longwinded, and puts the learner in a good position to use the templating engine. I also appreciate that some non-focus areas were covered, inclusion of the bootstrap JS framework and Spring / Thymeleaf security integration are greatly appreciated.

I also appreciate that later in the course the intro is reduced to a quiet animated graphic vs. the full multi-media experience that the outro contains - when watching many videos in a row having the outro feed right into the intro of the next lesson with both having full fanfare is very distracting. It would be good if this was likewise fixed in the earlier lessons as well.

Thank you for a great class! I'll be looking into your other Spring classes!

results.content: Instructor audio is clear, his explanations are very thorough. I am using Eclipse rather than IntelliJ, but he gave so much detail in the setup that it was easy to get my project started. I also liked the coding assignments. Without writing your own code  it's easy to be fooled into thinking you know a topic better than you actually do.

I am using Eclipse rather than IntelliJ, but he gave so much detail in the setup that it was easy to get my project started. I also liked the coding assignments. Without writing your own code it's easy to be fooled into thinking you know a topic better than you actually do.

results.content: This course is really great for starting out with thymeleaf, the instructor is quite knowledgeable and explains thymeleaf in details, the course serves well in building confidence for any team that want to start using thymeleaf for their next projects.

results.content: Really good. A thorough tour of core Thymeleaf concepts that will take you from a beginning to intermediate understanding of the engine. Great hands-on with live-coding examples. John is an excellent instructor. I'd love to see some more advanced functionality, such as parameterizable fragment signatures, flexible layouts, logging, and decoupled template logic. Maybe in future?

Great hands-on with live-coding examples. John is an excellent instructor. I'd love to see some more advanced functionality, such as parameterizable fragment signatures, flexible layouts, logging, and decoupled template logic. Maybe in future?

results.content:
Giving low rating because there is very few part of the lecture are evaluable. Here are my opinion why:
- the course first 25% is not about thymeleaf at all (if the course was much more longer then it's ok, but it's not soo long...)
- very annoying intro and outro in every video! (+15-20 sec spam)
- in every video too many twaddle about what happened in the previous video and what will happen in the next....
- most of the codes are prewritten, I prefer writing the code along with the teacher, I think you learn much more this way.
To summerize the total 4.5h hour video in reality more like about 1.5h in reality, which is a shame... 

Positive:
 - the little evaluable part is a really great introduction to thymeleaf, but I'd like see more on the topic!
results.content_html:

results.content: It's pretty good, but I find the music and animation jingle at the start and end of each module jarring. I like to put my own music on in the background when I do Udemy courses and watch a bunch of modules back to back. If you watch the modules like this you get 2 jingles exactly the same back to back. Some of the modules are only a few minutes long so it's possible for it to be triggered many times in the space of an hour, which can be pretty off-putting. Otherwise 5/5.

results.content:
I really enjoyed the course. I felt that it successfully taught and demonstrated the use of the 20% needed to get started creating our own pages using thymeleaf along side Spring Boot. I also think that John's usage of git commits at the beginning and end of each section is fantastic. Not only does this expose students to a highly important tool they should be using, but it also means that if you make a mistake during any lecture you can look at the working snapshot that John provides with github and have an easier time finding your mistakes.

I highly recommend this course if you are new to using Thymeleaf with Spring Boot!
results.content_html:

I highly recommend this course if you are new to using Thymeleaf with Spring Boot!

results.content:
Basically, there is not that much here. Just a basics that I learned from other courses that briefly explained and implemented thymeleaf as a supportive technology. There goes a credit for thymeleaf developers as it is really easy to understand.
Each video follows the same pattern: In first third, author explains in the future tense what he will do. Second third, briefly explains what author already did off screen in Intellij. Third third is actually the same as first third, but in the past tense.
In general, more time is spent on Spring, rather than thymeleaf (it seems that there is really not that much to tell about thymeleaf at all). Also, author should consider that not everyone has finance to buy IntelliJ when he stated: "I do not see any reason why should anyone use Eclipse over Intellij".
results.content_html:

results.content: yes; so far it's been good and very timely, as I had decided prior to this to try and figure out Thymeleaf on my own after getting a Spring project up and running. It's finally clicking how to do everything I'm trying to get done.

results.content_html: I would like to see more code examples and talk summary as slides rather than the speaker's face in the recture.

results.content:
Hi John,
your course on Thymeleaf with spring boot course was amazing, but it looked outdated with spring boot 1.
I would greatly appreciate it if you can update the course material for spring boot 2 with thymeleaf 3 because i ran into issues when i was following your course and doing my coding on thymeleaf fragments which seems to be a little different.
results.content_html:
Hi John,
your course on Thymeleaf with spring boot course was amazing, but it looked outdated with spring boot 1.
I would greatly appreciate it if you can update the course material for spring boot 2 with thymeleaf 3 because i ran into issues when i was following your course and doing my coding on thymeleaf fragments which seems to be a little different.

results.content: This course is great in context of coverage of topics. However when concept id being explained, rather than showing code on screen, instructor video is showing up and easy to get distracted. Also there are 64 videos as a part of this course and I feel it a bit of overkill instructor starting video saying name and website name (5 sec min) and ending video with animated short video for spring framework guru (8-10 sec), this adds up to approx 16 min of repetitive video saying instructor name and website video
results.content_html: This course is great in context of coverage of topics.
